title: Woman fired for being ‘too good looking’
text:
Woman says she was fired for being ‘too good looking’ February 21, 2017 1:41pm A freelance television worker claims she was dropped by her employer because she was “too good looking”. Picture: The Sun. Tom Gillespie The Sun Share on Twitter 
A FREELANCE television worker claims she was dropped by her employer because she was “too good looking”. 
Emma Hulse has said she was just five minutes into an eight-hour shift when her manager said: “Are you not doing catwalks? Why are you not at the front of house?” reports The Sun . Emma Hulse is pursuing a career in television. Picture: The Sun. Source: The Sun 
She then claims the manager, who has not been named, sent her home after he “suggested we go for a drink”, the Evening Standard reports . 
The firm Unit TV have admitted how the situation played out and have confirmed the relevant manager no longer works for them. 
Emma describes herself as a runner, production assistant, and camera operating executive on her TalentManager profile. 
The 24-year-old from Mayfair in London said: “We were supposed to finish at 6pm and I got there for 9.30am and when I got there this other runner started explaining to me what I should do. Emma describes herself as a runner, production assistant, and camera operating executive on her TalentManager profile. Picture: The Sun Source: The Sun 
“Then they send me on a run. Then my agent text me that I’m no longer required. 
“I got there and spoke to the line manager and he asked me, ‘Are you a model? Are you not doing catwalks, why are you not at the front of house?’ 
“I was wearing a lipstick but from my perspective I was not inappropriate. I was wearing a shirt and trousers. I really didn’t think I looked inappropriate. 
“Then he took my number, he suggested we go for a drink.” Sarah’s agent sent her a text message to tell her that the employer no longer wanted her. Picture: The Sun Source: The Sun 
She added: “I was quite disappointed to be sent home. I didn’t really know what to do. 
“Maybe that company employs plain looking people and maybe if you don’t look that way they don’t take you, maybe I was a distraction. 
“I do camera operating as well, I work for many different companies and no one has sent me home because of the way I look. Especially within a creative agency you should be free to wear what you want.” 
Adam Luckwell, owner of the company, said: “We found there were a number of things we were not happy with. 
“We decided not to continue with the employment and terminated the contract within three months. 
“We felt he was a bad fit for us and some of the things he was doing was not in line with the company’s policy.”
